resources.name: AWS Billing
resources.description: View and monitor the primary metrics of Billing.

markdown.markdownText:
![image.png](data:image/png;base64,)
### AWS Billing Dashboard

This customizable dashboard provides comprehensive insights and real-time monitoring of your AWS spending, offering unparalleled visibility into cost trends and budget management. This dashboard tracks key metrics such as total estimated charges, daily and monthly expenditure, and identifies top spending services to ensure optimal budget management and cost efficiency.

Benefits:

Improved Cost Management: Proactive monitoring helps identify spending patterns and optimize resource allocation, ensuring efficient budget management and cost savings.
Enhanced Financial Visibility: Early detection of potential cost overruns minimizes unexpected expenses and ensures financial consistency, safeguarding your budget and resources.
Optimized Spending: Gain insights into resource usage and allocation to optimize costs and avoid unnecessary spending, ensuring cost-effective AWS management.
Simplified Financial Management: Consolidated monitoring simplifies financial oversight, facilitating quick identification and resolution of issues, and streamlining operations across your AWS resources.
Comprehensive Overview: This comprehensive dashboard ensures you can effectively manage and optimize your AWS spending, enhancing performance, reliability, cost-efficiency, and overall operational efficiency.

Details of integration to bring in AWS Billing - [AWS Billing and Cost Management Documentation](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cost-management/latest/userguide/billing-what-is.html)

### Use Cases Covered

* **Current Charges Section**: Monitor total estimated charges for the current month and daily estimates to understand spending trends.

* **Historical Charges Section**: Analyze the total estimated charges for the previous month to identify budget trends and anomalies.

* **Service Insights Section**: Identify top spending services and areas eating into your budget to optimize resource allocation and cost management.

These use cases provide a comprehensive view of the primary metrics for monitoring AWS Billing, allowing for effective financial management and optimization. You can modify the widgets by clicking on the widget you want to customize and editing the query in the bottom query bar to tailor the monitoring system to your specific needs.

widgets.title: Total Estimated Charges in This Month

resources.name: AWS CloudWatch Metric Streams
resources.description: View of key metrics related to the health, performance, and status of AWS CloudWatch Metric Streams, including metric update activity, data ingestion rates, publishing error rates, and total metrics processed to ensure real-time monitoring, seamless data streaming, and high observability across AWS environments.

markdown.markdownText:
**AWS CloudWatch Metric Streams**
![AWS CloudWatch Metric Streams](https://icon.icepanel.io/AWS/svg/Management-Governance/CloudWatch.svg) 
**Amazon CloudWatch Metric Streams** enables you to continuously stream CloudWatch metrics to destinations such as Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose, where you can route them to storage and analytics services like Amazon S3, Redshift, or third-party monitoring platforms. This real-time streaming capability allows for low-latency, high-throughput metric ingestion, making it ideal for advanced analytics, custom dashboards, and large-scale monitoring.

**Details of integrations to bring in AWS CloudWatch Metric Streams metrics -** [AWS CloudWatch Metric Streams](https://coralogix.com/docs/cloudwatch-metricstreams-kinesis-data-firehose/)

**Use Cases Covered**

* Metric Stream Health Overview
    * Metric Update
* Error Monitoring
    * Publish Error Rate
* Performance Metrics
    * Total Metric Update

**More about performance monitoring of AWS CloudWatch Metric Streams Service** [here](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudWatch/latest/monitoring/CloudWatch-metric-streams-monitoring.html)

resources.name: AWS CloudWatch Metric Streams
resources.description: View of key metrics related to the health, performance, and status of AWS CloudWatch Metric Streams, including metric update activity, data ingestion rates, publishing error rates, and total metrics processed to ensure real-time monitoring, seamless data streaming, and high observability across AWS environments.

resources.name: AWS DynamoDB
resources.description: View and monitor the primary metrics of DynamoDB

markdown.markdownText: ![dynamoDB](https://icon.icepanel.io/AWS/svg/Database/DynamoDB.svg) Amazon DynamoDB is a fast, flexible and fully managed non-relational database service for any scale. DynamoDB enables customers to offload the administrative burdens of operating and scaling distributed databases to AWS so that they do not have to worry about hardware provisioning, setup and configuration, throughput capacity planning, replication, software patching or cluster scaling. This dashboard is part of the out-of-box Amazon DynamoDB extension and provides visibility to and alerting on key performance metrics. **Details of integrations to bring in Amazon DynamoDB logs -** [here](https://coralogix.com/docs/cloudwatch-metricstreams-kinesis-data-firehose/)

**Use Cases Covered**

* Successful Request Latency (The latency of successful requests to DynamoDB or DynamoDB Streams during the specified time period)
* Write Throttled Requests (Requests to DynamoDB that exceed the provisioned Write capacity units for a table or a global secondary index)
* Read Throttled Requests (Requests to DynamoDB that exceed the provisioned Read capacity units for a table or a global secondary index)
* Pending Replication Count (The number of item updates that are written to one replica table, but that have not yet been written to another replica in the global table)
* Replication Latency (The elapsed time between an updated item appearing in the DynamoDB stream for one replica table, and that item appearing in another replica in the global table)
* % of Provisioned Read/Write Capacity Consumed (The number of Read/Write capacity units consumed over the specified time period for both provisioned and on-demand capacity)
* System Errors (The requests to DynamoDB or DynamoDB Streams that generate an HTTP 500 status code during the specified time period)
* User Errors (Requests to DynamoDB or DynamoDB Streams that generate an HTTP 400 status code during the specified time period)
* Transaction Conflict (Rejected item-level requests due to transactional conflicts between concurrent requests on the same items)
* Returned Bytes (The number of bytes returned by GetRecords operations during the specified time period)
* Returned Records (The number of stream records returned by GetRecords operations during the specified time period)
* Returned Items (The number of items returned by Query, Scan or ExecuteStatement [Select] operations during the specified time period)

More about performance monitoring of Amazon DynamoDB[ here](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/metrics-dimensions.html)

widgets.title: % of Provisioned Read Capacity Consumed By GlobalSecondaryIndexName
% of Provisioned Write Capacity Consumed By GlobalSecondaryIndexName

resources.name: AWS EKS
resources.description: View and monitor the primary metrics of Amazon EKS.

markdown.markdownText:
#### **AWS EKS (Elastic Kubernetes Service)**

 AWS EKS is a fully managed Kubernetes service that simplifies the process of running Kubernetes on AWS. With EKS, you can easily deploy, manage, and scale containerized applications using Kubernetes, without needing to maintain the Kubernetes control plane. EKS integrates seamlessly with other AWS services, such as IAM, VPC, and Load Balancers, to provide a secure and reliable environment for your applications. It supports both self-managed and fully managed worker nodes, giving you the flexibility to choose the best option for your workload.

 This dashboard complements the out-of-the-box AWS EKS extension, providing visibility into and alerting on key performance metrics. It helps you monitor cluster health, node performance, pod status, and overall application performance, ensuring that your Kubernetes workloads are running efficiently and effectively on AWS.

Details of integration to bring in AWS EKS - [https://docs.aws.amazon.com/eks/latest/userguide/monitoring-your-cluster.html](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/eks/latest/userguide/monitoring-your-cluster.html)

#### **Setting up Container Insights on Amazon EKS and Kubernetes** 
Container Insights is supported on Amazon EKS versions 1.23 and later.

The overall process for setting up Container Insights on Amazon EKS or Kubernetes is as follows:

1. Verify that you have the necessary prerequisites.
2. Set up the [Amazon CloudWatch Observability EKS](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudWatch/latest/monitoring/Container-Insights-setup-EKS-addon.html) add-on or the CloudWatch agent on your cluster to send metrics to CloudWatch.

# **Use Cases Covered**

**Worker Node Section**Monitor the status of worker nodes in an AWS EKS cluster by regularly checking key metrics such as **CPU utilization**, **memory usage**, and **network traffic**. Ensure **overall availability** of worker nodes, confirming they are online and reachable.

**Pod Section**Track the lifecycle and status of pods in an AWS EKS cluster, including states like **running**, **failed**, **pending**, and **termination**. Monitor pod **health** and **resource usage** (CPU and memory consumption) while detecting any errors or failures.

**Container Section**Monitor the status of containers running in an AWS EKS cluster. Track the **lifecycle** of each container, including **running**, **waiting**, **restart**, and **termination**. Monitor **health** and **resource usage** (CPU and memory consumption) and identify errors or failures during execution.

You can customise the widgets by clicking on the widget you want to modify and editing the query in the bottom query bar.

widgets.title: Count Of Node
widgets.description: The total number of worker nodes in the cluster.

widgets.title: Count Of Failed Node
widgets.description: The number of failed worker nodes in the cluster.

widgets.title: Node CPU Utilization %
widgets.description: The total percentage of CPU units being used on the nodes in the cluster.

promqlQuery.value: avg(amazonaws_com_ContainerInsights_node_cpu_usage_total_avg{NodeName!="", ClusterName=~"{{ClusterName}}", cloud_region=~"{{cloud_region}}", cloud_account_id=~"{{cloud_account_id}}"}) by (ClusterName, NodeName) / avg(amazonaws_com_ContainerInsights_node_cpu_limit_avg{NodeName!="", ClusterName=~"{{ClusterName}}", cloud_region=~"{{cloud_region}}", cloud_account_id=~"{{cloud_account_id}}"}) by (ClusterName, NodeName) * 100

widgets.title: Node Filesystem Utilization In %
widgets.description: The total percentage of file system capacity being used on nodes in the cluster.

widgets.title: The Total Number Of Bytes  Transmitted And Received Over The Network Per Node
widgets.description: The total number of bytes per second transmitted and received over the network per node in a cluster.

widgets.title: Count of running pods
widgets.description: Indicates that all containers in the pod are running.

widgets.title: Count of failed pod
widgets.description: Indicates that all containers in the pod have terminated, and at least one container has terminated with a non-zero status or was terminated by the system.

widgets.title: Count of pending pod
widgets.description: Indicates that the pod has been accepted by the cluster but one or more of the containers has not become ready yet.

widgets.title: Count of succeeded pod
widgets.description: Indicates that all containers in the pod have successfully terminated and will not be restarted.

widgets.title: Average pod cpu utilization by cluster %
widgets.description: The percentage of CPU units being used by pods.

widgets.title: Average pod memory utilization by cluster %
widgets.description: The percentage of memory currently being used by the pod or pods.

widgets.title: The number of bytes per second being received over the network by the pod.
widgets.description: The number of bytes per second being received over the network by the pod.

widgets.title: The number of bytes per second being transmitted over the network by the pod.
widgets.description: The number of bytes per second being transmitted over the network by the pod.

widgets.title: Count of running containers
widgets.description: Reports the number of containers in the pod which are currently in the Running state.

widgets.title: Count of waiting containers
widgets.description: Reports the number of containers in the pod which are in the Waiting state.

widgets.title: Count of containers restarts
widgets.description: The total number of container restarts in a pod.

widgets.title: Count of terminated containers
widgets.description: Reports the number of containers in the pod which are in the Terminated state.

widgets.title: Average containers cpu utilization by cluster %
widgets.description: The percentage of CPU units being used by the container.

widgets.title: Average containers memory utilization by cluster %
widgets.description: The percentage of memory units being used by the container.

resources.name: AWS Redshift
resources.description: View and monitor the primary metrics of AWS Redshift.

markdown.markdownText:
![image.png](data:image/png;base64,)
### AWS Redshift Dashboard

This customizable dashboard provides comprehensive insights and real-time monitoring of your AWS Redshift clusters, offering unparalleled visibility into their performance and usage. This dashboard tracks key metrics such as CPU utilization, database connections, throughput, IOPS, and latency to ensure optimal Redshift performance and reliability.

Benefits:

Improved Performance: Proactive monitoring helps identify and optimize underperforming nodes, ensuring efficient resource utilization and optimal performance.
Enhanced Reliability: Early detection of potential issues minimizes service disruptions and ensures operational consistency, safeguarding your data and applications.
Optimized Costs: Gain insights into resource usage and allocation to optimize costs and avoid unnecessary spending, ensuring cost-effective Redshift management.
Simplified Management: Consolidated monitoring simplifies management, facilitating quick identification and resolution of issues, and streamlining operations across your Redshift clusters.
Comprehensive Overview: This comprehensive dashboard ensures you can effectively manage and optimize your AWS Redshift clusters, enhancing performance, reliability, cost-efficiency, and overall operational efficiency.

Details of integration: [AWS CloudWatch Metric Streams with Amazon Data Firehose](https://coralogix.com/docs/cloudwatch-metricstreams-kinesis-data-firehose/) or [Collect CloudWatch Metrics with Telegraf](https://coralogix.com/docs/collect-cloudwatch-metrics-telegraf/)

### Use Cases Covered:

* **CPU and Connections Section**: Monitor average CPU utilization and database connections to ensure efficient resource usage and understand connection load.
* **Status Section**: Track health status and maintenance mode duration to maintain cluster reliability and minimize downtime.
* **Throughput Section**: Analyze TX and RX throughput to evaluate network performance and capacity for data transfer.
* **I/O Performance Section**: Observe read and write IOPS by node to ensure optimal data processing performance.
* **Latency Section**: Monitor read and write latency by node to identify potential delays and optimize data retrieval and processing.


You can customize the widgets by clicking on the widget you want to modify and editing the query in the bottom query bar.

promqlQuery.value: sum(amazonaws_com_AWS_Redshift_ReadIOPS_sum{NodeID!="", cloud_account_id=~"{{cloud_account_id}}", cloud_region=~"{{cloud_region}}", NodeID=~"{{NodeID}}"}) / sum(amazonaws_com_AWS_Redshift_ReadIOPS_count{NodeID!="", cloud_account_id=~"{{cloud_account_id}}", cloud_region=~"{{cloud_region}}", NodeID=~"{{NodeID}}"}) by (NodeID)

sum(amazonaws_com_AWS_Redshift_WriteIOPS_sum{NodeID!="", cloud_account_id=~"{{cloud_account_id}}", cloud_region=~"{{cloud_region}}", NodeID=~"{{NodeID}}"}) / sum(amazonaws_com_AWS_Redshift_WriteIOPS_count{NodeID!="", cloud_account_id=~"{{cloud_account_id}}", cloud_region=~"{{cloud_region}}", NodeID=~"{{NodeID}}"}) by (NodeID)

sum(amazonaws_com_AWS_Redshift_WriteLatency_sum{NodeID!="", cloud_account_id=~"{{cloud_account_id}}", cloud_region=~"{{cloud_region}}", NodeID=~"{{NodeID}}"}) / sum(amazonaws_com_AWS_Redshift_WriteLatency_count{NodeID!="", cloud_account_id=~"{{cloud_account_id}}", cloud_region=~"{{cloud_region}}", NodeID=~"{{NodeID}}"}) by (NodeID)

resources.name: AWS Redshift Serverless
resources.description: View and monitor the primary metrics of AWS Redshift Serverless.

markdown.markdownText:
![image.png](data:image/png;base64,)
### AWS Redshift Serverless Dashboard

The AWS Redshift Serverless Dashboard provides comprehensive insights and real-time monitoring of your Redshift Serverless environments, offering enhanced visibility into their performance and usage. This dashboard tracks key metrics such as compute capacity, database connections, query runtime, and snapshot storage to ensure optimal Redshift Serverless performance and reliability.

Benefits:

Improved Performance: Proactive monitoring helps identify and optimize underperforming resources, ensuring efficient compute capacity utilization and optimal performance.
Enhanced Reliability: Early detection of potential issues minimizes service disruptions and ensures operational consistency, safeguarding your data and applications.
Optimized Costs: Gain insights into resource usage and allocation to optimize costs and avoid unnecessary spending, ensuring cost-effective Redshift Serverless management.
Simplified Management: Consolidated monitoring simplifies management, facilitating quick identification and resolution of issues, and streamlining operations across your Redshift Serverless environments.
Comprehensive Overview: This comprehensive dashboard ensures you can effectively manage and optimize your AWS Redshift Serverless environments, enhancing performance, reliability, cost-efficiency, and overall operational efficiency.

Details of integration to bring in AWS Redshift Serverless - [AWS Redshift Serverless Documentation](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/redshift/index.html)

### Use Cases Covered:


* **Compute and Connections Section**: Monitor compute capacity and database connections to ensure efficient resource allocation and understand connection load.
* **Query Performance Section**: Analyze query runtime breakdown and compute seconds to evaluate query efficiency and identify optimization opportunities.
* **Storage Section**: Track snapshot storage to understand data backup and storage usage, ensuring efficient data management and retrieval.


You can customize the widgets by clicking on the widget you want to modify and editing the query in the bottom query bar.

promqlQuery.value: sum(sum_over_time(amazonaws_com_AWS_Redshift_Serverless_ComputeCapacity_sum{cloud_account_id=~"{{cloud_account_id}}", cloud_region=~"{{cloud_region}}", Workgroup=~"{{Workgroup}}"})) by (Workgroup) / sum(sum_over_time(amazonaws_com_AWS_Redshift_Serverless_ComputeCapacity_count{cloud_account_id=~"{{cloud_account_id}}", cloud_region=~"{{cloud_region}}", Workgroup=~"{{Workgroup}}"})) by (Workgroup)  or on () vector(0)

resources.name: Amazon EC2
resources.description: View of key metrics relating to the health and performance of deployed Amazon EC2 instances.

markdown.markdownText: ![Amazon EC2](https://icon.icepanel.io/AWS/svg/Compute/EC2.svg) Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) provides on-demand, scalable computing capacity in the Amazon Web Services (AWS) Cloud.Using Amazon EC2 reduces hardware costs so you can develop and deploy applications faster.You can use Amazon EC2 to launch as many or as few virtual servers as you need, configure security and networking, and manage storage. This dashboard is part of the out-of-box Amazon EC2 extension and provides visibility to and alerting on key performance metrics. **Details of integrations to bring in Amazon EC2 -** [here](https://coralogix.com/docs/cloudwatch-metricstreams-kinesis-data-firehose/)

**Use Cases Covered**

* CPU Utilization (percentage of physical CPU time that Amazon EC2 uses to run the EC2 instance)
* Disk Read Bytes (bytes read from all instance store volumes available to the instance)
* Disk Write Bytes (bytes written to all instance store volumes available to the instance)
* Network In (number of bytes received by the instance on all network interfaces)
* Network Out (number of bytes sent out by the instance on all network interfaces)
* Network Packets In (number of packets received by the instance on all network interfaces)
* Network Packets Out (number of packets sent out by the instance on all network interfaces)
* CPU Credit Usage (number of CPU credits spent by the instance for CPU utilization)
* CPU Credit Balance (number of earned CPU credits that an instance has accrued since it was launched or started)
* CPU Surplus Credit Balance (number of surplus credits that have been spent by an unlimited instance when its CPU Credit Balance value is zero)
* CPU Surplus Credits Charged (number of spent surplus credits that are not paid down by earned CPU credits, and which thus incur an additional charge)
* EBS Read Ops (completed read operations from all Amazon EBS volumes attached to the instance in a specified period of time)
* EBS Write Ops (completed write operations to all Amazon EBS volumes attached to the instance in a specified period of time)
* EBS Read Bytes (bytes read from all EBS volumes attached to the instance in a specified period of time)
* EBS Write Bytes (bytes written to all EBS volumes attached to the instance in a specified period of time)
* EBS IO Balance% (provides information about the percentage of I/O credits remaining in the burst bucket)
* EBS Byte Balance% (provides information about the percentage of throughput credits remaining in the burst bucket)
* StatusCheckFailed\_System (reports whether the instance has passed the system status check in the last minute)
* StatusCheckFailed\_Instance (reports whether the instance has passed the instance status check in the last minute)
* StatusCheckFailed\_AttachedEBS (reports whether the instance has passed the attached EBS status check in the last minute)
* EC2 API Successful Calls (number of successful API calls made to EC2)
* EC2 API Request Limit Exceeded (number of API calls exceeded the maximum number of allowed API requests)
* EC2 API Client Error (request made to the EC2 API is invalid or improperly formatted)
* EC2 API Server Error (EC2 service itself encounters an issue and cannot fulfill a valid request)

    More about performance monitoring of Amazon EC2[ here](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/viewing_metrics_with_cloudwatch.html)

resources.name: Amazon Relational Database Service (RDS)
resources.description: View of key metrics relating to the health and performance of deployed AWS RDS functions.

markdown.markdownText:
**Amazon RDS**
![AWS RDS](https://icon.icepanel.io/AWS/svg/Database/RDS.svg)
 Amazon Relational Database Service (RDS) is a managed service that makes it easy to set up, operate, and scale a relational database (PostgreSQL, MySQL, MariaDB, SQL Server, Oracle, Db2) in the cloud. It provides cost-efficient and resizable capacity, while managing time-consuming database administration tasks, freeing you to focus on your applications and business.

This dashboard is part of the out-of-box Amazon RDS extension and provides visibility to and alerting on key performance metrics.

**Details of integrations to bring in Amazon RDS logs -** [here](https://coralogix.com/docs/cloudwatch-metricstreams-kinesis-data-firehose/)

**Use Cases Covered**

* CPU Utilisation (percentage of CPU utilisation)
* Freeable Memory or Memory Available (amount of available random access memory)
* Disk Available (amount of available local storage for each instance)
* Database Connections (number of client network connections to the database instance)
* Read IOPS (number of disk read I/O operations per second)
* Write IOPS (number of disk write I/O operations per second)
* Read Latency (amount of time it takes for a read operation to be completed)
* Write Latency (amount of time it takes for a write operation to be completed)
* Network Throughput (measures the incoming/outgoing(received) network traffic on the database instance)
* Swap Usage (portion of the disk used by the operating system as virtual memory when the physical memory (RAM) is fully utilized)
* Cache Hit Ratio (percentage of requested data that is found in the cache compared to the total number of data requests)
* Avg Disk Queue (The number of outstanding I/Os (read/write requests) waiting to access the disk.)
* RDS Service Limit (usage of AWS Trusted Advisor service limits for Amazon RDS instances)

More about performance monitoring of Amazon RDS[ here](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonRDS/latest/UserGuide/rds-metrics.html)

resources.name: Istio Mesh Dashboard
resources.description: View of key metrics relating to the health and performance of Istio Mesh Service.

markdown.markdownText:
**Istio Mesh Dashboard**
![Istio Mesh Dashboard](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/istio/istio.io/master/static/img/istio-social.png)  

Istio is an open source service mesh that layers transparently onto existing distributed applications. Istio’s powerful features provide a uniform and more efficient way to secure, connect, and monitor services. Istio is the path to load balancing, service-to-service authentication, and monitoring – with few or no service code changes. 

**Details of integrations to bring in Istio Mesh Dashboard metrics -** [Istio-Mesh-Dashboard](https://coralogix.com/docs/cloudwatch-metricstreams-kinesis-data-firehose/)

**Use Cases Covered**

* Traffic Metrics
    * Mesh Requests - Total Requests/ Success Rate / Failures / Duration
 * Pilot XDS 
     * Endpoints Connected Pilot Using XDS
     * XDS Pushes
     * Rejected Events
      * Errors
 * Sidecar injection
      * Injection Requests
      * Skipped Injections
      * Injection Time
 * Pilot K8S
      * Events For K8S Config
 * Istiod Resource Usage
      * Memory Usage 
      * JVM Usage
      * GC Duration
      * GRPC Latency
      * Virtual Memory Size
 * Proxy 
      * Proxy Convergence Time 
      * Proxy Queue Time
      * XDS Proxy Requests
      * XDS Proxy Response
  * Istio Build
      *   Istio Components by Version
      * Managed Cluster
      * Uptime

**More about performance monitoring of Istio Mesh Service** [here](https://istio.io/latest/docs/reference/commands/pilot-discovery/#metrics)

resources.name: Kubernetes Complete Observability - Coralogix Helmchart Supported
resources.description: View of key metrics relating to the health and performance of Kubernetes.

markdown.markdownText:
![image.png](data:image/png;base64,)

### Kubernetes Complete Observability {Coralogix Helm Chart supported}

This customizable dashboard provides comprehensive insights and real-time monitoring of your Kubernetes clusters, offering unparalleled visibility into the health and performance of your workloads and nodes. This dashboard tracks key metrics such as resource utilization, pod status, node availability, and network traffic to ensure optimal Kubernetes performance and reliability.

**Benefits:**
Improved Resource Management: Proactive monitoring helps optimize the allocation of CPU, memory, and disk resources across nodes and pods, ensuring efficient utilization and performance.
Enhanced Cluster Health: Early detection of potential issues minimizes downtime and ensures that nodes and pods remain healthy and responsive.
Optimized Costs: Gain insights into resource utilization and cluster scaling to avoid unnecessary resource consumption and reduce operational costs.
**Details of integration to bring in Kubernetes Observability Dashboard** - [Kubernetes Complete Observability: Basic Configuration](https://coralogix.com/docs/opentelemetry/kubernetes-observability/kubernetes-complete-observability-basic-configuration/)

### Use Cases Covered

* **Cluster Overview**: Monitor key metrics like node count, pod count, and cluster health to get a comprehensive view of your Kubernetes environment's current state.
* **Resource Utilization**: Track CPU, memory, and disk usage across nodes and pods to ensure efficient resource allocation and prevent bottlenecks or over-provisioning.
* **Node Health Monitoring**: Keep track of node status and readiness to ensure optimal availability and performance of your Kubernetes cluster.
* **Pod Lifecycle**: Monitor pod creation, deletion, and error states to ensure workloads are running as expected and to troubleshoot issues quickly.
* **Network Traffic**: Analyze network traffic and packet flow between nodes, services, and external endpoints to identify potential network issues and ensure proper connectivity.
* **Application Performance**: Monitor the performance of applications deployed in Kubernetes, ensuring they meet operational standards and service level agreements.
* **Container Metrics**: Gain insights into the status of containers, including resource utilization and error rates, to ensure containers are performing optimally.

You can duplicate dashboard  to create a custom K8sObservability journey suitable to your needs.

dataprimeQuery.text:
source spans| filter $d.tags['http.url'].contains('frontend-proxy') | groupby ($m.timestamp/1h).formatTimestamp('%F %H:%M:%S') as hour,$l.serviceName, $d.tags['http.url'] as http_url agg count() as total_requests,
    avg($d.duration)/1000000 as avg_duration_seconds,
    min($d.duration)/1000000 as min_duration_seconds,
    max($d.duration)/1000000 as max_duration_seconds,
    percentile(0.95, $d.duration)/1000000 as p95_duration_seconds,
    percentile(0.99, $d.duration)/1000000 as p99_duration_seconds
| orderby avg_duration_seconds desc

resources.name: System Monitoring - Linux instances (copy)
resources.description: Gives insights into your Host health and CPU, Memory, Disk and Network usage.

markdown.markdownText:
* **CPU/Memory/Disk Utilization Thresholds:**
    * 0% - 70% → 🟢 Normal
    * 70% - 90% → 🟠 Warning
    * Above 90% → 🔴 Critical

**Note: Threshold values are configurable.**

dataprimeQuery.text: source spans | filter tags['http.url'].contains('frontend') | groupby tags['http.url'], $l.serviceName
